studentDialog:
Here are some made-up words in English. I would like you to read as many as you can. Do not spell the words, but read them.  For example, this made-up word is: “ut”.

Let’s practise: Please read this word [point to the word: dif]. 

     [If the child responds correctly]: “Good, This word is “dif.”

     [If the child does not respond correctly, say]: This made-up word is “dif.”

Now try another one: please read this word [point to the next word: mab]. 

     [If the child responds correctly, say]: “Good, this made-up word is “mab.”

     [If the child does not respond correctly say]: This made-up word is “mab.”

When I say “Begin,” start here [point to first word] and read across the page [point].  Point to each word and read it in a loud voice. Read as quickly and carefully as you can. If you come to a word you do not know, go on to the next word. Put your finger on the first word. Ready? Begin.
enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the sheet of non-words in the student stimuli booklet. Read the instructions.

Start the timer when the child reads the first non-word.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect words by touching that word on the screen until it turns blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching again until it returns to grey.

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next word and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped word as incorrect.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final letter read by touching it so that a bracket appears, then press "Next".

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

Early stop rule: If the child does not provide a single correct response for the first 5 words, the screen will flash red and stop the timer. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
name: EGRA Task 4. Simple unfamiliar nonword decoding
transitionComment: Good effort!  Let's go on to the next section.

studentDialog:
Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-C1
 
Here are some numbers. 1, 2, and 3, what number goes here?
[if correct]
That’s correct, 4. Let’s do another one.
[if incorrect]
The number 4 goes here. Say the numbers with me. [Point to each number] 1, 2, 3, 4.  4 goes here. Let’s do another one. 
 
Here are some numbers. 17, and 19, what number goes here?
[if correct]
That’s correct, 18. Let’s do some more.
[if incorrect]
The number 18 goes here. Say the numbers with me. [Point to each number] . . . 17, 18, 19.  [Point to the dash] 18 goes here. Let’s do some more.
enumeratorHelp:
Student stimulus sheets EGMA F1-C1 (practice), F1-C2 (exercise), and F1-C3 (exercise).

Follow along on your screen and mark any item as either correct or incorrect. Your selected answer will turn yellow. If the child makes 4 successive errors, the screen will "grey out" any remaining items. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.

If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.

studentDialog:
Good morning.  My name is ____  and I live in _____.  I’d like to tell you a little bit about myself.  [Number and ages of children; favourite sport, radio or television program, etc.]

1. What do you like to do when you are not in school? [Wait for response; if student is reluctant, ask question 2, but if they seem comfortable continue to verbal consent]

2. What games do you like to play?

•    I work with the Ministry of Education and we are trying to understand how children learn to read and learn mathematics.  You were picked by chance.

•    We would like your help in this.

•    We are going to play a reading and math game. 

•    Using this device, I will see how long it takes you to read.  

•    This is NOT a test, it will not affect your grade at school, and I will not write down your name.

•    I will also ask you other questions about your family and language.

•    You do not have to participate if you do not wish to.  

•    After we begin, if you don't want to answer a question, we can skip that question or stop.  

•    Do you have any questions? Are you ready to get started?
enumeratorHelp: Establish a playful and relaxed rapport with the child through a short conversation (see example topics below). The child should perceive the assessment almost as a game to be enjoyed rather than a test. Use this time to identify in what language the child is most comfortable communicating. Read aloud slowly and clearly ONLY the sections in boxes.
name: Verbal Consent

studentDialog:
I have some problems that I am gong to ask you to solve for me. Here are some things to help you count. You can use them or your fingers if you need them, but you don’t have to use them. Listen very carefully to each problem. If you need, I will repeat the problem for you. Okay, let’s get started.

Foya has 2 mangoes. Helen has 3 mangoes. How many mangoes do they have altogether?

[If the child answers correctly, say] That’s right. They have five mangoes altogether. Let’s do some more.  

[If the child answers incorrectly, say] They have five mangoes altogether. Watch me. [Use the counters and read the problem, demonstrating 2 counters for Foya and 3 counters for Helen.] When we count add them altogether, we get five mangoes. Let’s do some more. 

Now you will work out more questions that I will read to you. Remember some of these questions may be hard even for older children, so do your best. Remember, you can use these or your fingers to help you answer the questions.

[Point to the counters.] Okay, let’s get started.
enumeratorHelp:
There is no stimulus sheet for this task.

Give the child paper on which to write and a pencil with which to write as well as a set of 20 counters.

Follow along on your screen and mark any item as either correct or incorrect. Your selected answer will turn yellow.

If the child makes 4 successive errors, the screen will "grey out" any remaining items. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS (and does not attempt to use counters, fingers, paper, or pencil), point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.
If the child is working but does not respond to an item after 1 MINUTE, mark item as wrong and move on.

The “[pause and check]” in each problem indicates that you should be certain that the child understands what you have said before continuing.  You may want to ask, “Do you understand?”
name: EGMA Task 5. Word Problems

Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-D2

Show the child the sheet in the student stimulus booklet as you read the instructions. 
Start the timer when the child attempts the first item. 
Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect item by touching that item on the screen - it will turn blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the item again - it will return to grey.

If the timer reaches 0 before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final item attempted by touching it so that a bracket appears. Then press “Next.”
If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.

studentDialog:
Here are some words. I would like you to read me as many words as you can (do not spell the words, but read them).
 
For example, this word is: “CAT”.
 
1. Now you try:  [point to the word “mat” and say] please read this word:
 
                            [If correct]: Good, this word is “mat.”
 
                           [If incorrect]: This word is “mat.”
 
2. Now try another one:  [point to the word “top”] please read this word:
 
                           [If correct]: Good, this word is “top.”
 
                          [If incorrect]: This word is “top.”
 
Do you understand what are you supposed to do? When I say “begin,” read the words as best as you can.  I will keep quiet and listen to you, unless you need help. Ready? Begin.
enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the sheet of words in the student stimuli booklet. Read the instructions.

Start the timer when the child reads the first word.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect words by touching that word on the screen until it turns blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching again until it returns to grey.

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next word and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped word as incorrect.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final letter read by touching it so that a bracket appears, then press "Next".

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. Touch the last letter so the bracket appears, then press "Next".

Early stop rule: If the child does not provide a single correct response for the first 5 words, the screen will flash red and stop the timer. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
name: EGRA Task 3. Familiar Word Identification

prompt: back ten tin
name: pa_df_init_snd4

studentDialog:
Here is a page full of letters of the ENGLISH alphabet. Please tell me the NAMES of as many letters of the alphabet as you can. Not their sounds, but their names.

For example, the name of this letter [point to the letter O] is “Oh”.

Let’s practice: Tell me the name of this letter [point to the letter V]:

[If the child responds correctly say]: Good, the name of this letter is “vee.”

[If the child does not respond correctly, say]: The name of this letter is “vee”.

Now try another one: Tell me the name of this letter [point to the letter L]:

[If the child responds correctly, say]: Good, the name of this letter is “ELL.”

[If the child does not respond correctly, say]: The name of this letter is “ELL.”

When I say “Begin,” start here [point to first letter] and go across the page [point]. Point to each letter and tell me the name of that letter in a loud voice. Read as quickly and carefully as you can. If you come to a letter you do not know, go on to the next letter. Put your finger on the first letter. Ready? Begin.
enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the sheet of letters in the student stimuli booklet as you read the instructions.

Start the timer when the child reads the first letter.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect letters by touching that letter on the screen until it turns blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the screen again until it returns to grey.

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next letter and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped letter as incorrect.

If the student provides the letter sound rather than the name, say: “Please tell me the NAME of the letter”. This prompt may be given only once during the exercise.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final letter read by touching it so that a bracket appears. Then press “Next.”

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, STOP the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The red bracket will automatically be placed on the last letter.  Verify that your scores are correct, then press “Next”.

Early stop rule: If the child does not provide a single correct response for the first 10 items, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
name: EGRA Task 1. Letter Name Knowledge
transitionComment: Good effort!  Let's go on to the next section.

studentDialog:
Here is a short story. I want you to read this aloud.  When you finish, I will ask you some questions about what you have read.  Do you understand what are you supposed to do?

When I say “begin,” read the story as best as you can. I will keep quiet and listen to you, unless you need help. Ready? Begin.
enumeratorHelp:
Show the child the story in the stimuli booklet. Read the instructions to the child and conduct the examples.  

Start the timer when the child reads the first word.

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect word by touching that word on the screen - it will turn blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the word again - it will return to grey. 

Stay quiet, except if the child hesitates for 3 seconds. Then point to the next word and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped word as incorrect.

If the timer runs out before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final word read by touching it so that a red bracket appears, then press “Next”.

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last word. If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

Early stop rule: If the child does not read a single word correctly from among the words necessary to answer the first comprehension question, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
name: EGRA Task 5A. Oral Reading Fluency Passage
transitionComment: REMOVE THE READING PASSAGE FROM IN FRONT OF THE CHILD before pressing 'Next'.

studentDialog:
Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-B1

Look at these numbers. [Indicate Example #1, the numbers 10 and 4.]  Tell me which number is bigger.
[if correct]
That’s correct, 10 is bigger. Let’s do another one.
[if incorrect]
The bigger number is 10. [Point to 10] This is 10. [Point to 4] This is 4.  10 is bigger than 4. Let’s do another one.
 

Look at these numbers. [Indicate Example #2, the numbers 8 and 12.] Tell me which number is bigger.
[if correct]
That’s right, 12 is bigger.  Let’s continue.
[if incorrect]
The bigger number is 12. [Point to 8] This number is 8. [Point to 12] This is 12.  12 is bigger than 8. Let’s continue.
enumeratorHelp:
Student stimulus sheets EGMA F1-B1 (example), F1-B2 (exercise) and F1-B3 (exercise)

Show the child the sheet in the student stimulus booklet as you read the instructions. 
Follow along on your screen and mark any item as either correct or incorrect. Your selected answer will turn yellow.

If the child makes 4 successive errors, the screen will "grey out" any remaining items. Say, “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and go on to the next subtask.
If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.

prompt: 8. Which word begins with a different sound? </br> can  girl  cold
name: pa_diff_init_sound8

studentDialog:
This is a listening exercise. I’m going to say THREE words. ONE of them begins with a different sound. Please tell me which word BEGINS WITH A DIFFERENT SOUND than the other words.

For example: “lost”, “map”, “like”. Which word begins with a different sound?

 [If correct:] Good, “map” begins with a different sound.

 [If incorrect:] “lost ”, “map”, “like”.  “map” begins with a different sound than “lost” and “like”.

Now let’s try another one: “train”, “trip”, “stop”. Which word begins with a different sound?

 [If correct:] Good, “stop” begins with a different sound.

 [If incorrect:] “train”, “trip”, “stop”.  “stop” begins with a different sound than “train” and “trip”.
 

Ready? Let’s begin.
enumeratorHelp:
This is NOT a timed exercise and THERE IS NO STUDENT SHEET. Read the instructions to the child and conduct all examples as written.

Pronounce each set of words clearly and slowly (about 1 word per second) ONE TIME.  If the child does not respond after 3 seconds, mark as no response and continue to the next item. 

Early stop rule: If the child responds incorrectly or does not respond to the first five sets of words, items 6 – 10 will be greyed out automatically. Say “Thank you!”, discontinue this subtask, and press "next" to continue to the next subtask.
name: EGRA Task 2. Phonemic Awareness
transitionComment: Good effort!  Let's go on to the next section.

studentDialog:
Here are some addition (plus) problems. Tell me the answers to as many as you can. If you don’t know an answer, move to the next problem.

Are you ready? … Start here, [point to first problem] go across, [sweep finger across first row] and tell me the answer to each problem.
enumeratorHelp:
Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-D1

Show the child the sheet in the student stimulus booklet as you read the instructions. 
Start the timer when the child attempts the first item. 
Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect item by touching that item on the screen - it will turn blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the item again - it will return to grey.

If the timer reaches 0 before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final item attempted by touching it so that a bracket appears. Then press “Next.”
If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.
name: EGMA Task 4A. Addition

studentDialog:
Here are some numbers. I want you to point to each number and tell me what the number is. I will tell you when to begin and when to stop.
 

[point to first number] Start here.  Are you ready? . . . Start.
 

What number is this?
enumeratorHelp:
Student stimulus sheet EGMA F1-A

Show the child the sheet in the student stimulus booklet as you read the instructions. 
Start the timer when the child attempts the first item. 

Follow along on your screen and mark any incorrect item by touching that item on the screen - it will turn blue. Mark self-corrections as correct by touching the item again - it will return to grey.

If the timer reaches 0 before the last item is read, the screen will flash red and the timer will stop. Tell the child to stop. Mark the final item attempted by touching it so that a bracket appears. Then press “Next.”

If the child reaches the last item before the screen flashes red, stop the timer as soon as the child reads the last letter. The bracket will automatically appear on the last word.  Verify your scores, and then press "Next".

If the child does not respond to an item after 5 SECONDS, point to the next item and say, “Please go on.” Mark the skipped item as incorrect.
name: EGMA Task 1. Number Identification

studentDialog:
I am going to read you a short story aloud ONCE and then ask you some questions. Please listen carefully and answer the questions as best as you can. Do you understand what are you supposed to do?

*****

Musu goes to the Bong Town School every day on a motor bike.

One day, Musu could not get a motor bike to take her to school because it was raining and they were all busy.

Musu did not want to get wet. Then, one old man said, “You can have my son’s raincoat.” Musu was happy. She did not have to be wet at school.
enumeratorHelp:
This is NOT a timed exercise and THERE IS NO STUDENT SHEET. Read the text in the Student Dialog box.

Read the passage aloud ONLY ONE TIME, and slowly (about 1 word per second).
name: EGRA Task 6. Listening Comprehension
